Description: The "Brain" of the simwheel interfacing the wheel to the computer
Tracks rotation of the wheel in high fidelity, using a magnet
High strength bearings that allow the rotating assembly to spin freely
More high strength bearings, once again, keeping the assembly together in order to allow it to spin freely
High performance fan to blow cold air into the motor/rotating assembly to keep it cool.
Heatsinks to be glued all over the motor and the electronics to keep the assembly cool
1200W psu with adequate damping to handle the nessecary power to give the motor torque.
M5 heatsets, as m5 and 3d printed parts are the most common thread/fastening method used here

Part name:: M5 x 55mm Hex Socket Head Cap Screws
Description: While i have plenty of m5 fasteners to use in this design, It does call for a large number of m5x55 SCHS screws which i do not have.

I used a lot of this tape in my badminton career (storytime guys?) and it's common practice to wrap grip tape around steering yokes/wheels. Especially considering that it will be printed from a fiber reinforced material, the grip tape both protects my hands and makes it much easier on the hands to use for extended periods of time.
12mm rod holder to hold the motor in place.

Part name:: Cat6A+ Bulk Raw Ethernet Cable Black Bulk 700MHz 20 ft 23AWG
Description: Ethernet plenum is used oftentimes in DIY simwheels and professional simwheels as it can preserve encoder signals very well and is cost effective. The plenum here will be used and needs a lot of length to accomodate the wheel rotation and to preserve encoder signals. This one is meant for burial, which means it has been given a stronger shielding to withstand what are going to be aggressive rotation forces and possible entanglement.
